text: The Quijos rocket frog (Hyloxalus fuliginosus) is a frog. It lives in Ecuador. Scientists think it could also live in Venezuela and Colombia. ==Body== The adult male frog is 23.6–24.3 mm long from nose to rear end and the adult female frog is 27.8–32.5 long. The skin of the frog's back is dark green-brown in color. There is a line down each side of the body. The frog's belly is very dark in color with tiny white spots. The male frogs and female frogs have different colors on their bellies: the male frogs have gray chests and female frogs have cream-white chests with or gray spots. The male frog's male organs are white in color. ==Home== People see this frog in cloud forests. People see them during the day under rocks and logs. People have seen this frog between 572 and 1926 meters above sea level. One of the places this frog lives is a protected parks: Parque Nacional Cayambe Coca. ==Young== Scientists think this frog's tadpoles swim in streams. ==Danger== Scientists say this frog is in big danger of dying out because it lives in a small place. They think people cut down trees to build farms and make places for cows to eat grass. Bad chemicals in the water can kill this frog. Other animals that humans brought to the frog's home by mistake can also hurt this frog. ==References== Category:Frogs of South America
title: Hyloxalus fuliginosus
